reviews.content: An uncomplicated beginner's whisky without corners and edges for a very moderate price. You can also try something like that, especially in times when prices only seem to know the way up.
reviews.nose: Fruity, malty and with a good dose of vanilla. There are yellow aromas, which are very restrained. Nothing stings, nothing disturbs, nothing stands out.
reviews.taste: Very soft and fruity with lots of vanilla and malt. Slight herbal notes, some brioche, a little honey and caramel. Again, yellow fruits dominate without any flaws in the taste. The palate is flattered and the whisky is once again recommended as Easy Dram or perfect beginner.
reviews.finish: Short to medium length with fruit and sweetness on the palate. Again, error-free and easily accessible.

reviews.content: Here we have another workhorse of the blend industry, since most of Aberfeldy's production ends up as key component of Dewar's. The nose of this 12-year-old Highlander is unimposing, grainy and slightly acidic with apple cider, heather honey and hints of vinegar. On the palate, it arrives silky, light and malty sweet before turning aromatic and indistinctly sour in the development. A surprisingly milky aftertaste with almonds, muesli and a touch of oak rounds off the experience. It's probably not a very memorable single malt, but nice enough to give it a try.RATING: 3.0/5.0 stars ≙ 80 pts → AVERAGE

reviews.content: Sweet apples and oak drifted languidly out of the glass as white flowers and digestif biscuits followed close behind. A touch of beeswax and old paper lingered with the scent of a musty wood shop in the background. Light-bodied, the flavor profile was richer than I expected, with plenty of honey and apples on waxed paper— homemade breakfast grain bars sweetened with dried fruits and honey. A touch of vanilla and coconut jam lingered further in with plenty of oak and a kiss of peppery herbs. The finish was medium to short with malty pastries, honey, and oak.This was far more enjoyable than I expected, echoing my reaction to the Dewar’s 12 Year I also brought home from Aberfeldy. I would pour this over that, and while I do not often stock mass market products at home (I have long since fallen to the esoteric siren’s song of independent bottlers), I would absolutely take a pour of this if I were at an event or bar and I wanted a solid single malt. This will not hold your attention, but that is not the point, it should fade nicely into the background of an evening.

The color is of course a beautiful, warm gold color. A rich and smooth whisky. As soon as you smell your whisky you will smell soft notes of spices and a very light smoky scent. Tilt it slightly and you will smell more fruity aromas. While tasting the whisky you can taste hints of: chocolate, caramel, honey, spices and peat. A nice full whisky that you like to roll through your mouth. With its full and dry aftertaste, spicy aftertaste and hints of oranges and honey, you will enjoy its taste for a long time to come.

reviews.finish: The sweetness of the palate continues, now on vanilla cake, honey and cacao. Some nutty and spicy elements linger, together with that subtle whiff of smoke.

03/05/2024 - 30 ml + 50 ml with ice In fact, one of the worst value for money in Single Malt. I'm always tempted to buy it just because of the packaging, which I think is beautiful, but after this blind test it put me off for good. Interestingly, legend has it that it is the basis of Dewar's blended blends, but I find Dewar's 12 so pleasant, different from this neutral and bland Aber"hell"dy.
reviews.nose: Herbal, cereals, light malt. Dry and simple, the alcohol appears but doesn't bother you. Some yellow fruit in the background. Take wood that is more old than new. Alcohol permeates everything, but like grain alcohol. With water it becomes slightly sweeter, but it opened up an acetic. Incredible presence of cereals. Before revealing, I thought it was a dry blended. With ice, the yellow fruits appear more, as well as acetic, vanilla and malt. No alcohol.
reviews.taste: Dry, grain alcohol but without aggression. Vanilla appeared and the wood is definitely new. Yeast, malt and cereals. With water malted cereals, but simple unmalted cereals predominate, such as some dried grass. Only new wood tannin. Okay, it has a slight vanilla. Simple, it's not unpleasant, but it's almost neutral. On slightly sweet ice with fresh fruits, new wood and cereals. No alcohol.
reviews.finish: Short, light malt and new wood, plus the ubiquitous grain alcohol.

reviews.content: Aberfeldy 12YO is a quite good whisky. It’s a simple, smooth, and easy drinkable. It appears with sweet bee-wax, honey, caramel and white fruits notes on nose. The palate is sweet, waxy with honey, oak and light wood fire notes. The finish is a middle with vanilla, spices, oak, caramel, apples and wood coal dust.

It was a bottle I bought with no expectations and drank roughly, but after a few months of airing, it became really delicious. In particular, it is impressive that the sweet and bitter taste of chocolate lingers for a long time in the finish.
reviews.nose: honey, flowers, sugar, cloves At first, there is a sweet and bitter honey scent, followed by a flower-like floral scent. A sweet sugary scent that comes with sherry and a slightly clove-like spice.
reviews.taste: Malt, ripe banana, apple, some nuts, hints of oak. It has the unique nutty sweetness of malt. Afterwards, I felt the sweetness and scent of a ripe banana and a bit of citrus like an apple. Next you can find some nuttiness and hints of oak.
reviews.finish: Orange zest, butter, ginger, dark chocolate The finish is long. It feels fresh like orange zest, followed by a slightly oily taste like butter. The spice of ginger right after the butter. The ginger-like feeling lasts quite a long time. As the ginger gradually decreases, the nutty, sweet and bitter taste of dark chocolate (about 70%?) is felt.

reviews.content: I think this might be perfect for anyone who prefers smooth whiskies, for people that normally drink blends, or maybe to start a whisky tasting session. Do not get me wrong, this is pretty good, but personally I would not buy a bottle. There is certainly no harm in taking a shot if you want to have an easy evening without any challenges.
reviews.nose: Opens with the floral side of honey and barley sugar. It is extremely friendly and maybe a little bit too flat. Gentle notes of cashew nuts, macaroons, biscotti, cake and butterscotch. There are not many things in the nose that displeases me, no rough edges, no exciting turns, you get it.. it might be slightly boring. Oh and Please do not add water, chances are that you drown it.
reviews.taste: Honey, toffee and barley sugar. A good balance from the start (again stay clear from water) with gentle notes of sweetness and floralness (florality?). Wether’s Original, a hint of sunflower oil and seeds, and it gets a bit of a bitter edge in the finish. Could be something like amaretto liquor, but we are not sure because it does not stay long.
reviews.finish: More of the above.

reviews.content: Tasted on a Virgin Atlantic flight. Here the whisky comes in quadruple measures only, so I’ll try to get the notes out of the way asap. This is my first Aberfeldy, and my first whisky review after months of living bone-dry trying to get the covid out of my cardiovascular system. Note to self: high-intensity sports and boozing are a no-no when you have a nasty virus in your system. We’re better now so, cheers!Overall this was quite a positive surprise, with obvious investment in the distillery’s wood policy and a charismatic highland make. I think it could do rather well with a more natural presentation. Looking at the bottle here, et looks like the distillery puts out the same OB with “limited edition: batch 2095” on it year in year out. That’s rather embarrasing isn’t it? Perhaps they don’t expect anyone to care enough to pay attention. Another instance of weird mass consumer mixed with “niche” product marketing. Look out perfumery, we’re coming for your shallow world of obvious untruths!
reviews.nose: A surprising amount of weight, clearly of the Highlands. Aberfeldy seems to have a rather dull reputation, but this isn’t bad at all. The wide cut reminds of Pultney, actually. It’s a good mix of Bourbon and modern sherry Casks, all seemingly clean with minimal sulphur if at all. Indeed, this cask mix is similar to OB Pulteneys as well. Very toffeed, with a good dose of citruses and tropical fruits, both sweeter (banana) and sourer (passion fruit)- very nice! Malty, with lots of spirit sulphur, green fruits and balanced spices. An aura of honeyed yellow florals.
reviews.taste: This is 40% if memory serves - does well for that level of dilution. The spirit seems quite weighty and the first-fill casks add their hefty sweetness, so it doesn’t feel overly dilute, still held together nicely, creamy if somewhat syrupy texture. The palate is similar to the nose, if a bit fresher on the green and citrus fruits, verging into the tropical. Still lots of sulphury weight. Feels well put together, with a nice balance of sweet, sour and spicy. Quite sherried in the development, with decent wood and darker spices (clove, pepper), the sweetness keeps it balanced though.
reviews.finish: As anyone could have predicted, the finish is weakest in this minimum-strength bottling. It doesn’t get too dry, but we’re mainly on the wood and spice now, with some residual cask sweetness and perhaps a little malt. Overall much more neutral than the palate, with alcohol coming through. Still, there’s no obvious flaws, they could bottle this at higher strength.

Aberfeldy 12 year old is a solid whisky that I would happily recommend as a starter malt to someone commencing their whisky journey. It offers a good balance of sweetness and cask spice, whilst still sticking true to the promise of the Golden Dram with honeyed notes and flavours firmly in the driving seat. Of course, as an entry-point whisky it’s none too surprising to see this at 40% - I’d be very interested in a 12 year old cask strength version were that ever created.https://www.thedramble.com/tastings/aberfeldy/aberfeldy-12-year-old/
reviews.nose: Honey and fruit. Honey is immediate and pronounced. It is accompanied by vanilla, pineapple, orange peels, butterscotch and barley water. There’s a light herbalness in the background – some mint and maybe some pine. Cask influence is kept on the down low initially, but ginger is still perceivable.
reviews.taste: Light, delicate and a little lacking in body, but entirely pleasant in terms of arrival. Spice and bitterness now come out to play with cinnamon, ginger and bitter toffee all playing a part. There’s a combination of both fresh and dried fruits and berries here and the honey and vanilla remain firmly in place and translating well from the nose. There’s a good balance between sweetness and bitterness and some interesting notes of burnt caramel and toasted almonds.
reviews.finish: Short to medium in length and bringing orange zest and ginger spice.

This is accompanied by a dusty note. With water, first a few pieces of chocolate with a few Nusssplittern out. This is followed by malted sugar, a few oak chips and chocolate-coated orange sticks.
reviews.taste: The citrus notes of the nose are not detectable at first, but gradually develop. Malt and a potpourri of spices complete the whole thing. Water makes the taste minimal creamy. Then suddenly some chocolate, before beautiful oak notes & bitter orange take over the scepter. Everything embedded in a slight dustiness.
reviews.finish: Here too an idea nut & malt, otherwise a full, round dryness. Water again catches soft citrus notes before it gets dry in the mouth; accompanied by oak, spices, wafer-thin caramel and a hint of orange.

reviews.content: My first tasting of the whisky was pretty devastating. Since there are a lot of positive reviews overall, I had to buy a new sample. Although it largely corresponds to what I remember, I would like to adjust a few points, in particular I remembered the finish as being much worse.
reviews.nose: Orange, honey, vanilla, caramel, chocolate and a little lemon, the combination is very appealing, although the orange is almost a bit too strong for me. For 12 years it seems very fresh, almost too fresh.
reviews.taste: After the pleasant smell, the taste was rather disappointing and immediately reminded me of Loch Lomond Original: Very faint of malt, vanilla, green apple and some lemon.
reviews.finish: Edit: It remains a fairly short and flat finish, but my original 58 points doesn't do the whisky justice, I increased it to 65 points. Old review: Was there something? It sounds mean, but that was the most boring finish I've ever had on a whisky, a touch of vanilla, a second, nothing else.

reviews.finish: Quite sweet, but the oak comes through a bit, along with some cinnamon.
